status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
nealrichardson commented on code in PR #14281:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14281#discussion_r984480770


##########
r/R/dplyr-across.R:
##########
@@ -23,7 +23,7 @@ expand_across <- function(.data, quos_in) {
     quo_expr <- quo_get_expr(quo_in[[1]])
     quo_env <- quo_get_env(quo_in[[1]])
 
-    if (is_call(quo_expr, "across")) {
+    if (is_call(quo_expr, c("across", "if_any", "if_all"))) {

Review Comment:
   Be sure to update docgen.R to reflect what is supported in `across()` now. You may also want to add entries there for `if_any` and `if_all` (they're tidyselect?) since they're supported too but not automatically included in the docs since they don't go through `register_binding`

thisisnic commented on code in PR #14281:

##########
r/R/dplyr-across.R:
##########
@@ -23,7 +23,7 @@ expand_across <- function(.data, quos_in) {
     quo_expr <- quo_get_expr(quo_in[[1]])
     quo_env <- quo_get_env(quo_in[[1]])
 
-    if (is_call(quo_expr, "across")) {
+    if (is_call(quo_expr, c("across", "if_any", "if_all"))) {

Review Comment:
   Done!

thisisnic commented on code in PR #14281:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14281#discussion_r991430442


##########
r/tests/testthat/test-dplyr-across.R:
##########
@@ -278,3 +278,25 @@ test_that("ARROW-14071 - function(x)-style lambda functions are not supported",
     regexp = "Anonymous functions are not yet supported in Arrow"
   )
 })
+
+test_that("if_all() and if_any() are supported", {
+
+  expect_across_equal(
+    quos(if_any(everything(), ~is.na(.x))),
+    quos(is.na(int) | is.na(dbl) | is.na(dbl2) | is.na(lgl) | is.na(false) | is.na(chr) | is.na(fct)),
+    example_data
+  )
+
+  expect_across_equal(
+    quos(if_all(everything(), ~is.na(.x))),
+    quos(is.na(int) & is.na(dbl) & is.na(dbl2) & is.na(lgl) & is.na(false) & is.na(chr) & is.na(fct)),
+    example_data
+  )
+
+  expect_across_equal(
+    quos(if_all(everything(), ~is.na(.x))),
+    quos(is.na(int) & is.na(dbl) & is.na(dbl2) & is.na(lgl) & is.na(false) & is.na(chr) & is.na(fct)),
+    example_data
+  )

Review Comment:
   ```suggestion
   ```

ursabot commented on PR #14281:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14281#issuecomment-1274793867

   ['Python', 'R'] benchmarks have high level of regressions.
   [ursa-i9-9960x](https://conbench.ursa.dev/compare/runs/9a223b6b1758499ea3277db10980da7a...a1d228ce880e48d58964aa6a12d59333/)

jorisvandenbossche commented on PR #14281:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14281#issuecomment-1275681790

   I got notified in another PR (which was merged after this one) about potential perf regression, but so I think it is this PR that gives a slight slowdown in some benchmarks. The biggest regression (TPCH-08) seems a flaky measurement, but for TPCH-16 it seems persistent (although it's only a very small slowdown, no idea if it is significant)

thisisnic commented on PR #14281:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14281#issuecomment-1275784028

   > I got notified in another PR (which was merged after this one) about potential perf regression, but so I think it is this PR that gives a slight slowdown in some benchmarks. The biggest regression (TPCH-08) seems a flaky measurement, but for TPCH-16 it seems persistent (although it's only a very small slowdown, no idea if it is significant)
   
   What's a good way to investigate this? I wouldn't expect a slowdown from this PR, but can't rule it out entirely.

jorisvandenbossche commented on PR #14281:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14281#issuecomment-1275802610

   I suppose the easiest would be to first try to get the code behind that benchmark running locally (but not familiar with the R benchmarks for what's the easiest way to so this), and then if you can run it locally, then checking if you can reproduce the slowdown, and if so you can profile both cases (but again, I don't know how to do that in R)

thisisnic commented on PR #14281:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14281#issuecomment-1275934268

   Thinking about this more, I'd expect it to be a tiny bit slower but not enough to affect the benchmarks, and given that this block of code has been added to other operations which are used in the benchmarks, I'd expect to see a regression in those too if it was problematic.  @jonkeane, I don't suppose you'd mind helping me take a look at this?

nealrichardson commented on PR #14281:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14281#issuecomment-1276047306

   I don't think this is concerning. None of the TPC-H queries have the features that this PR adds support for, so there's not much extra work being added that would add meaningful time. I did a quick benchmark of the "fast" path of the function in question here, and it costs <1ms: 
   
   ```
   > q <- rlang:::quos(a + b, c + d, e - f, f(a, b, c))
   > bench::mark(arrow:::expand_across(list(), q))
   # A tibble: 1 × 13
     expression                            min median itr/s…¹ mem_a…² gc/se…³ n_itr
     <bch:expr>                       <bch:tm> <bch:>   <dbl> <bch:b>   <dbl> <int>
   1 arrow:::expand_across(list(), q)   87.4µs 91.5µs  10755.  42.9KB    43.7  4923
   ```

jorisvandenbossche commented on PR #14281:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14281#issuecomment-1276054082

   Conbench also only identified the 0.01 and 0.1 scale factors as slowdown. The same benchmark but with scale factor 1 or 10 didn't show a consistent slowdown: https://conbench.ursa.dev/compare/benchmarks/44eef0b11f204c09bebde7b2a4050c98...07d114936d9c4b94b69aa712f0a8423e/ (which matches with what Neal is saying)

nealrichardson commented on PR #14281:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14281#issuecomment-1276150017

   Yeah, I've separately found those low scale factor benchmarks to be sensitive/flaky. They're useful in alerting when we add 10ms to the query assembly time (see also #13985), and those micro-regressions do add up if not addressed. But they're not all that noticeable if you're working with larger data.

fields.description: ARROW-11699 adds the ability to call dplyr::across() inside dplyr::mutate().  Once this is merged, we should also add the ability to do so within dplyr::filter().
